documents.text: Newton's First Law (Law of Inertia): What is Newton's first law? What is the law of inertia? An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion continues in motion with the same velocity unless acted upon by a net external force. This is the principle of inertia.

Newton's Second Law: What is Newton's second law? What is F = ma? What does F equals ma mean? Explain force equals mass times acceleration. F = ma, where F is the net force applied to an object, m is the object's mass, and a is its acceleration. This fundamental equation shows that force equals mass times acceleration. The greater the mass, the more force needed to achieve the same acceleration.

Newton's Third Law: What is Newton's third law? What is action reaction? Explain equal and opposite forces. For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. When object A exerts a force on object B, object B simultaneously exerts an equal force in the opposite direction on object A. These forces always occur in pairs.

Ohm's Law: What is Ohm's law? What is V = IR? Explain voltage current resistance relationship. Ohm's Law states V = IR, where V is voltage (electrical potential difference), I is current (flow of electric charge), and R is resistance (opposition to current flow). If you know any two values, you can calculate the third. Increasing resistance decreases current for a given voltage.

Kinetic Energy: What is kinetic energy? What is the kinetic energy formula? Explain KE = 1/2 mv squared. Kinetic energy is the energy of motion, given by KE = (1/2)mv², where m is mass and v is velocity. Kinetic energy increases with the square of velocity, so doubling speed quadruples kinetic energy.

Potential Energy: What is potential energy? What is PE = mgh? What is gravitational potential energy? Explain spring potential energy. Potential energy is stored energy due to position. Gravitational potential energy is PE = mgh, where m is mass, g is gravitational acceleration (9.8 m/s²), and h is height above a reference point. Elastic potential energy in a spring is PE = (1/2)kx², where k is the spring constant and x is displacement.

Work: What is work in physics? How do you calculate work? What is W = Fd? Work is defined as W = Fd cos(θ), where F is the applied force, d is displacement, and θ is the angle between force and displacement. Work is only done when force causes displacement in the direction of the force. Units are Joules (J).
documents.source: MCAT Physics => Work and Energy => Work

documents.text: Work-Energy Theorem: What is the work-energy theorem? How are work and kinetic energy related? The Work-Energy Theorem states that the net work done on an object equals the change in its kinetic energy: W_net = ΔKE = KE_final - KE_initial. This connects the concepts of work and energy.
documents.source: MCAT Physics => Work and Energy => Work-Energy Theorem

documents.text: Conservation of Energy: What is conservation of energy? Is energy conserved? In an isolated system with only conservative forces, total mechanical energy (KE + PE) remains constant. Energy can transform between kinetic and potential forms, but the sum stays the same: E_total = KE + PE = constant.

Power: What is power in physics? How do you calculate power? What is P = W/t? Power is the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred: P = W/t = Fv. The unit of power is the Watt (W = J/s). One horsepower equals 746 Watts. Power can also be expressed as P = ΔE/t.

Velocity: What is velocity? What's the difference between speed and velocity? Velocity is displacement per unit time (v = Δx/Δt) and is a vector quantity with both magnitude and direction. Speed is the magnitude of velocity and is a scalar. Average velocity equals total displacement divided by total time.

Acceleration: What is acceleration? How do you calculate acceleration? What are the kinematic equations? Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity: a = Δv/Δt. It's a vector quantity. Constant acceleration motion follows these equations: v = v₀ + at, x = x₀ + v₀t + (1/2)at², and v² = v₀² + 2a(x - x₀).

Projectile Motion: How does projectile motion work? What happens to horizontal and vertical velocity? Projectile motion: The horizontal component of velocity remains constant (no air resistance), while the vertical component is affected by gravity (a = -g = -9.8 m/s²). Time of flight depends only on vertical motion. Maximum range occurs at 45° launch angle: R = v₀²sin(2θ)/g.

Friction: What is friction? What is the friction formula? How do you calculate friction force? Friction force opposes motion and is given by f = μN, where μ is the coefficient of friction and N is the normal force. Static friction (μ_s) prevents motion from starting. Kinetic friction (μ_k) opposes ongoing motion. Always: μ_s > μ_k.

Centripetal Force and Acceleration: What is centripetal force? What is centripetal acceleration? Centripetal acceleration in circular motion is a_c = v²/r, pointing toward the center of the circle. The centripetal force required is F_c = ma_c = mv²/r. This force doesn't do work because it's perpendicular to displacement.

Inclined Plane: How does an inclined plane work? What forces act on a block on an incline? Inclined plane: A block on an incline of angle θ experiences acceleration a = g sin(θ) down the slope (no friction). The normal force is N = mg cos(θ). Gravity is resolved into parallel component (mg sin θ) and perpendicular component (mg cos θ).

Momentum: What is momentum? What is the momentum formula? Is momentum conserved? Momentum is p = mv, the product of mass and velocity. It's a vector quantity conserved in isolated systems. The Law of Conservation of Momentum states that total momentum before a collision equals total momentum after: p_initial = p_final.

Impulse: What is impulse? How are impulse and momentum related? Impulse equals the change in momentum: J = Δp = FΔt. A force applied over a time interval changes an object's momentum. This is the Impulse-Momentum Theorem: F_avg Δt = m Δv.

Series Circuits: How do series circuits work? What happens to current and voltage in series? Series circuits: Components are connected end-to-end in a single path. Current is the same through all components (I_total = I₁ = I₂). Voltages add (V_total = V₁ + V₂). Resistances add (R_total = R₁ + R₂).

Parallel Circuits: How do parallel circuits work? What happens to current and voltage in parallel? Parallel circuits: Components are connected across the same two points. Voltage is the same across all components (V_total = V₁ = V₂). Currents add (I_total = I₁ + I₂). For resistances: 1/R_total = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂.

Electrical Power: What is electrical power? How do you calculate power in a circuit? Electrical power is P = IV = I²R = V²/R, where P is power in Watts, I is current, V is voltage, and R is resistance. Energy consumed is E = Pt. In resistors, electrical energy is converted to heat (Joule heating).

Capacitors: How do capacitors work? What is capacitance? How much energy does a capacitor store? Capacitors store electrical charge according to Q = CV, where Q is charge, C is capacitance, and V is voltage. The energy stored in a capacitor is U = (1/2)CV² = (1/2)QV. Capacitance increases with larger plate area and smaller plate separation.

Wave Equation: What is the wave equation? How are wavelength and frequency related? Wave properties: All waves satisfy v = fλ, where v is wave speed, f is frequency (cycles per second), and λ is wavelength (distance per cycle). Period T = 1/f is the time for one complete cycle.

Doppler Effect: What is the Doppler effect? Why does frequency change with motion? Doppler Effect: Frequency changes when the source or observer moves. When approaching, observed frequency increases (f' > f). When receding, observed frequency decreases (f' < f). This applies to sound and electromagnetic waves.

First Law of Thermodynamics: What is the first law of thermodynamics? Is energy conserved in thermodynamics? First Law of Thermodynamics: ΔU = Q - W, where ΔU is the change in internal energy of a system, Q is heat added to the system, and W is work done by the system. This is conservation of energy for thermodynamic processes.

Second Law of Thermodynamics: What is the second law of thermodynamics? What is entropy? Second Law of Thermodynamics: Entropy of an isolated system always increases. Heat flows spontaneously from hot to cold. No heat engine can be 100% efficient - some energy must be wasted as heat to a cold reservoir.

Ideal Gas Law: What is the ideal gas law? What is PV = nRT? Ideal Gas Law: PV = nRT, where P is pressure, V is volume, n is number of moles, R is the gas constant (8.314 J/mol·K), and T is absolute temperature in Kelvin. This relates the state variables of an ideal gas.
documents.source: MCAT Physics => Thermodynamics => Ideal Gas Law

documents.text: Heat Transfer: How is heat transferred? What are the methods of heat transfer? Heat transfer occurs by three methods: Conduction (direct contact between molecules), Convection (bulk movement of fluids), and Radiation (electromagnetic waves). Heat flow is Q = mcΔT, where m is mass, c is specific heat, and ΔT is temperature change.

Torque: What is torque? How do you calculate torque? Torque is τ = rF sin(θ), where r is the distance from the axis of rotation, F is the applied force, and θ is the angle between r and F. Torque causes rotational acceleration. Units are N·m (Newton-meters).

Rotational Kinematics: What are the rotational kinematics equations? Rotational kinematics parallel linear kinematics: ω = Δθ/Δt (angular velocity), α = Δω/Δt (angular acceleration). The equations are: ω = ω₀ + αt, θ = θ₀ + ω₀t + (1/2)αt², ω² = ω₀² + 2α(θ - θ₀).

Density: What is density? How do you calculate density? Why does ice float? Density is ρ = m/V, where m is mass and V is volume. Units are kg/m³. An object floats in a fluid if its average density is less than the fluid's density. This explains why ice floats on water.

Pressure: What is pressure? How does pressure change with depth? Pressure is P = F/A, force per unit area. In fluids, pressure increases with depth: P = P₀ + ρgh, where ρ is fluid density, g is gravitational acceleration, and h is depth. Pascal's Principle states that pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted equally throughout.

Buoyancy and Archimedes Principle: What is buoyant force? What is Archimedes principle? Why do objects float? Buoyant force equals the weight of displaced fluid (Archimedes' Principle): F_b = ρ_fluid V_displaced g. An object floats when buoyant force equals its weight. An object sinks when its weight exceeds the buoyant force.

Simple Harmonic Motion: What is simple harmonic motion? What is Hooke's law? Simple harmonic motion (SHM): Objects in SHM experience restoring force F = -kx (Hooke's Law for springs). Period of a mass-spring system is T = 2π√(m/k). Period of a simple pendulum is T = 2π√(L/g), independent of mass.
documents.source: MCAT Physics => Oscillations => Simple Harmonic Motion

documents.text: Electric Field: What is an electric field? How do you calculate electric field? Electric field E is force per unit charge: E = F/q. Field from a point charge is E = kQ/r², where k is Coulomb's constant (8.99 × 10⁹ N·m²/C²), Q is the source charge, and r is distance. Electric field points away from positive charges and toward negative charges.

Electric Potential: What is electric potential? What is voltage? Electric potential (voltage) is V = kQ/r for a point charge. The change in electric potential energy when moving charge q through potential difference ΔV is ΔPE = qΔV. Work done moving a charge is W = qΔV.

Coulomb's Law: What is Coulomb's law? How do you calculate force between charges? Coulomb's Law: The force between two point charges is F = k(q₁q₂)/r², where q₁ and q₂ are the charges, r is the distance between them, and k is Coulomb's constant. Like charges repel, opposite charges attract.

Magnetic Force: What is magnetic force? How do magnets affect moving charges? Magnetic force on a moving charge: F = qvB sin(θ), where q is charge, v is velocity, B is magnetic field strength, and θ is the angle between velocity and field. Magnetic force is always perpendicular to both velocity and field (right-hand rule).

Lenses and Mirrors: How do lenses work? What is the lens equation? For thin lenses and mirrors, 1/f = 1/d_o + 1/d_i, where f is focal length, d_o is object distance, and d_i is image distance. Magnification M = -d_i/d_o = h_i/h_o. Converging lenses/mirrors have positive f, diverging have negative f.
documents.source: MCAT Physics => Optics => Lenses and Mirrors

documents.text: Snell's Law and Refraction: What is Snell's law? What is refraction? Snell's Law describes refraction: n₁ sin(θ₁) = n₂ sin(θ₂), where n is the index of refraction and θ is angle from the normal. Light bends toward the normal when entering a denser medium (higher n) and away when entering a less dense medium.
